title: PMS 2023 Exam
description: Complete 100-question PMS exam covering General Knowledge, Pakistan Affairs, Current Affairs, Geography, Everyday Science, Computer, Mathematics, Urdu, and Islamiat

questions.question: Where is the Kala Pani Jail located?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The Kala Pani Jail, officially known as the Cellular Jail, is located in Port Blair, part of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India. The name reflects the immense suffering of Indian freedom fighters who were imprisoned there by the British, isolated by the vast sea.

questions.question: To which country did Benjamin Franklin (1706-1790) belong?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Benjamin Franklin was one of the Founding Fathers of the United States.

questions.question: What was the profession of the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, before he became president?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Volodymyr Zelenskyy was a comedian and actor before becoming President of Ukraine.

questions.question: What is a subsidy?
options: A benefit given to individuals or businesses by the government
A tax imposed by the government
A loan given by the government
A fee charged by the government
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: A subsidy is a financial assistance provided by the government to support businesses or individuals.

questions.question: The book 'A Promised Land' was written by:
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Barack Obama wrote 'A Promised Land', his presidential memoir.

questions.question: Who is the author of the book 'In Search of Identity'?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Anwar el-Sadat, former President of Egypt, wrote 'In Search of Identity'.

questions.question: The ongoing Israel-Palestine crisis resulted from which 1947 Decision?
options: The UN Partition Plan for Palestine
The creation of the State of Israel
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The Israel-Palestine crisis has its roots in the United Nations General Assembly Resolution 181, also known as the Partition Plan, adopted on November 29, 1947. This plan proposed dividing British Mandate Palestine into two independent states—one for Jews and one for Arabs—which led to long-standing disputes and the ongoing conflict.

questions.question: The Houthi uprising is taking place in which country?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The Houthi movement is an armed political and religious group in Yemen.

questions.question: THALNOVA is a project of which sector?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: ThalNova is a 330MW lignite-fired power plant located at the Thar Coal Block-II in Sindh. It is part of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) and contributes to the energy sector, focusing on power generation through locally sourced coal.

questions.question: New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is also known as:
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is also known as the Big Board.

questions.question: Questionnaire method is used for collecting:
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Questionnaires are a primary data collection method used in research.

questions.question: The Order of the Rising Sun is an award of which country?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The Order of the Rising Sun is a Japanese order established in 1875.

questions.question: What does opportunity cost refer to?
options: The cost of purchasing an item
The cost of producing a good or service
Giving up the opportunity to choose the next best alternative
The amount of money spent on a product
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative foregone when making a decision.

questions.question: What is the recent goal of the International Monetary Fund (IMF)?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The IMF aims to promote modest economic growth and financial stability globally.

questions.question: Which country did Hitler attack first during World War II?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Nazi Germany invaded Poland on September 1, 1939, marking the start of World War II.

questions.question: Julian Assange is associated with which organization?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Julian Assange is the founder of WikiLeaks, an organization that publishes classified information.

questions.question: IMF funds are primarily provided for which of the following?
options: To ensure a stable exchange rate
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The IMF provides funds primarily to help countries maintain stable exchange rates and balance of payments.

questions.question: Carbon heat waves hit which continent:
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Europe has experienced severe heat waves in recent years due to climate change.

questions.question: Which from the following countries does not yield veto-power?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Only the five permanent members of the UN Security Council (US, UK, France, Russia, China) have veto power. Germany is not a permanent member.

questions.question: Who is called the Father of History?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Herodotus is known as the Father of History for his systematic collection and recording of historical events.

questions.question: 'Think and Grow Rich' was written by:
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Napoleon Hill wrote 'Think and Grow Rich', a classic self-help book on personal success.

questions.question: The 2024 Olympics were held in which country?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The 2024 Summer Olympics were held in Paris, France.

questions.question: Reuters is the news agency of:
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Reuters is a British news agency founded in London.

questions.question: Who is the author of the book 'Nineteen Eighty-Four'?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: George Orwell wrote the dystopian novel 'Nineteen Eighty-Four' published in 1949.

questions.question: What does a trade surplus mean?
options: A country imports more than it exports
A country exports more than it imports
A country has no international trade
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: A trade surplus occurs when a country's exports exceed its imports.

questions.question: The UN Charter was finalized at which conference?
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: The UN Charter was signed at the San Francisco Conference in 1945.

questions.question: World Environment Day is observed every year on:
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: World Environment Day is celebrated annually on June 5th.

questions.question: The book 'A Brief History of Time' is written by:
questions.subject: General Knowledge
questions.explanation: Stephen Hawking wrote 'A Brief History of Time', a popular science book about cosmology.

questions.question: The first Muslim ruler to introduce the system of price control in the sub-continent was:
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khilji implemented a comprehensive price control system in the Delhi Sultanate.

questions.question: The Battle of Plassey was fought between:
options: The British East India Company and the Nawab of Bengal
The British East India Company and the French East India Company
The Durrani Empire and the Marathas
The Marathas and the Nawab of Bengal
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: The Battle of Plassey (1757) was fought between the British East India Company and the Nawab of Bengal, Siraj ud-Daulah.

questions.question: The first EU-Pakistan Summit was held in:
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: The first EU-Pakistan Summit was held in Brussels in 2009.

questions.question: 'Cutting Edge' is the autobiography of:
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: Javed Miandad, the legendary Pakistani cricketer, wrote his autobiography 'Cutting Edge'.

questions.question: Who is the President of the Oxford Union from Pakistan?
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: Ibrar Kakar became the first Pakistani to be elected President of the Oxford Union.

questions.question: At the time of the partition of India, Kashmiris were divided into which parties?
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: At the time of partition, Kashmiris were divided between the National Conference and Muslim Conference.

questions.question: The Pakistan-China Boundary Agreement was signed on:
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: The Pakistan-China Boundary Agreement was signed on March 2, 1963.

questions.question: 'Kitab ul Hind' was written by:
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: Al-Biruni wrote 'Kitab ul Hind' (Book of India), a comprehensive study of Indian culture and science.

questions.question: The Central National Muhammadan Association was founded by:
questions.subject: Pakistan Affairs
questions.explanation: Syed Ameer Ali founded the Central National Muhammadan Association in 1877.

questions.question: In the early 1970s, Pakistan played a role in rapprochement between which two countries?
questions.subject: Current Affairs
questions.explanation: Pakistan played a crucial role in facilitating dialogue between the United States and China in the early 1970s, leading to President Nixon's historic visit to China.

questions.question: Cyril Ramaphosa is the president of which country?
questions.subject: Current Affairs
questions.explanation: Cyril Ramaphosa is the current President of South Africa.

questions.question: Who was awarded the UK Brain of the Year Award in 2023?
questions.subject: Current Affairs
questions.explanation: Amjad Saqib, founder of Akhuwat, was awarded the UK Brain of the Year Award in 2023.

questions.question: Which nation changed all criminal laws from colonial times in July 2024?
questions.subject: Current Affairs
questions.explanation: India replaced all colonial-era criminal laws with new codes in July 2024.

questions.question: What was the amount of the IMF loan provided to Pakistan in June 2023?
questions.subject: Current Affairs
questions.explanation: Pakistan received a $3 billion Stand-By Arrangement from the IMF in June 2023.

questions.question: What is a peninsula?
options: A landmass surrounded by water on three sides
A landmass surrounded by water on all sides
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: A peninsula is a piece of land that is surrounded by water on three sides.

questions.question: Which country is located north of the Gulf of Aden?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Yemen is located north of the Gulf of Aden.

questions.question: What are moraines?
options: Layers of sediment formed by rivers
Deposits of rock and debris left by glaciers
Erosion caused by wind in deserts
Volcanic materials ejected during an eruption
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Moraines are accumulations of rock and debris transported and deposited by glaciers.

questions.question: Which country is referred to as the Boot of Europe?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Italy is called the Boot of Europe due to its distinctive boot-like shape on the map.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the term 'Apartheid'?
options: A system of racial segregation and discrimination
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Apartheid was a system of institutionalized racial segregation that existed in South Africa from 1948 to 1994.

questions.question: How much percentage of Kashmir is under the jurisdiction of Pakistan:
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Approximately 40% of Kashmir is under Pakistan's administration (Azad Kashmir and Gilgit-Baltistan).

questions.question: What is the name of the ocean that lies between Europe and the United States?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: The Atlantic Ocean lies between Europe and the United States.

questions.question: Rhodesia is the old name of:
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Rhodesia was the former name of Zimbabwe before it gained independence in 1980.

questions.question: Warsak Dam is situated in which province?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Warsak Dam is located in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK) province, near Peshawar.

questions.question: Population density means:
options: The total number of people in a country
The ratio of rural to urban population
The total land area of a country
Number of people per square kilometer
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Population density is the number of people living per unit of area, typically per square kilometer.

questions.question: The largest island in the world is:
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Greenland is the world's largest island with an area of approximately 2.16 million square kilometers.

questions.question: Which of the following is the main reason for a Tsunami?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Tsunamis are primarily caused by underwater earthquakes that displace large volumes of water.

questions.question: The biggest district of Pakistan by area is:
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Chagai district in Balochistan is the largest district of Pakistan by area.

questions.question: The largest coal-producing country in the world is:
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: China is the world's largest coal producer, accounting for nearly half of global coal production.

questions.question: Mariupol is a city in which country?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Mariupol is a port city in southeastern Ukraine on the Sea of Azov.

questions.question: Samarkand is a major city in which country?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Samarkand is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in Central Asia, located in Uzbekistan. Note: The capital of Uzbekistan is Tashkent.

questions.question: The layers of the atmosphere are divided into how many layers?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: The atmosphere is divided into five main layers: Troposphere, Stratosphere, Mesosphere, Thermosphere, and Exosphere.

questions.question: Libya, Algeria, and Tunisia belong to which continent?
questions.subject: Geography
questions.explanation: Libya, Algeria, and Tunisia are all countries in North Africa.

questions.question: A solar cell converts solar energy into:
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Solar cells convert sunlight directly into electrical energy through the photovoltaic effect.

questions.question: A stone is a unit of which measurement?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: A stone is a unit of weight equal to 14 pounds or approximately 6.35 kilograms.

questions.question: Refractometer is used to determine:
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: A refractometer measures the refractive index of a substance and is commonly used to determine sugar content in solutions.

questions.question: For what achievement did James Chadwick receive the Nobel Prize in 1935?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: James Chadwick was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1935 for discovering the neutron.

questions.question: A geographic area containing plants, animals and other organisms interacting with each other and their environment forming a bubble of life is called:
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: An ecosystem is a community of living organisms interacting with their physical environment.

questions.question: The synthesis of an RNA molecule from DNA is called:
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Transcription is the process by which genetic information from DNA is copied to RNA.

questions.question: What is the process called when a cell engulfs another cell?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Phagocytosis is the process by which a cell engulfs solid particles or other cells.

questions.question: Thalassemia is due to abnormality in:
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Thalassemia is a genetic blood disorder caused by abnormal hemoglobin production.

questions.question: The number of babies produced per 1000 population:
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Natality (birth rate) is the number of live births per 1000 population in a given time period.

questions.question: What are Detritivores also called?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Detritivores are organisms that feed on dead organic matter and are also called decomposers.

questions.question: Which of the following is a nonrenewable source of energy?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Nuclear energy is considered nonrenewable because it relies on finite uranium resources.

questions.question: Light-year is a unit of:
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: A light-year is the distance light travels in one year, approximately 9.46 trillion kilometers.

questions.question: Animals that eat both plants and animals are known as:
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Omnivores are organisms that consume both plant and animal matter.

questions.question: What is the approximate percentage of water in carbonated drinks?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Carbonated drinks typically contain approximately 92% water.

questions.question: What is the use of a firewall in a computer?
options: Protect against unauthorized access and threats
questions.subject: Computer
questions.explanation: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.

questions.question: A set of rules for data communication is called:
questions.subject: Computer
questions.explanation: A protocol is a set of rules governing data communication between devices.

questions.question: What is the technique by which passwords and usernames can be stolen?
questions.subject: Computer
questions.explanation: Phishing is a fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive information by disguising as a trustworthy entity.

questions.question: Which of the following computer languages is written in binary codes only?
questions.subject: Computer
questions.explanation: Machine language consists entirely of binary code (0s and 1s) that can be directly executed by a computer's CPU.

questions.question: Silicon Valley is famous for:
questions.subject: Computer
questions.explanation: Silicon Valley in California is renowned as a global center for technology and computer innovation.

questions.question: If the mean of 7 terms is 40, the sum of the terms will be:
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation: Sum = Mean × Number of terms = 40 × 7 = 280

questions.question: A train covers a distance in 5 hours at 45 km/h. What speed is required to cover the same distance in 3 hours?
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation: Distance = 45 × 5 = 225 km. Required speed = 225 ÷ 3 = 75 km/h

questions.question: If the average marks of three batches of 55, 60 and 45 students respectively is 50, 55, and 60, then the average marks of all the students is:
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.question: Who was Ibn-e-Insha?
questions.subject: Urdu
questions.explanation: Ibn-e-Insha was a versatile Pakistani writer known for his poetry, travelogues, and columns.

questions.question: Before Damascus, which city was the capital of the Muslim Empire?
questions.subject: Islamiat
questions.explanation: Caliph Ali ibn Abi Talib moved the capital from Madina to Kufa in 656 CE. The capital was later shifted to Damascus by the Umayyads.

questions.question: Who is the author of the biography 'Muhammad: His Life Based on the Earliest Sources'?
questions.subject: Islamiat
questions.explanation: Martin Lings (1909-2005), also known as Abu Bakr Siraj ad-Din, was a British scholar who converted to Islam. He is best known for his acclaimed biography 'Muhammad: His Life Based on the Earliest Sources'.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of electric current?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: The Ampere (A) is the SI unit of electric current.

questions.question: Which gas is known as laughing gas?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Nitrous oxide (N₂O) is commonly known as laughing gas.

questions.question: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Mitochondria generate most of the cell's ATP (energy).

questions.question: Which planet is known as the Red Planet?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Mars is called the Red Planet due to iron oxide on its surface.

questions.question: What is the chemical formula for water?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Water has the chemical formula H₂O.

questions.question: Which vitamin is produced when skin is exposed to sunlight?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Vitamin D is synthesized in the skin when exposed to sunlight.

questions.question: What is the speed of light in vacuum?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: The speed of light in vacuum is approximately 3 × 10⁸ m/s.

questions.question: Which organ in the human body filters blood?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: The kidneys filter blood to remove waste products.

questions.question: What is the most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

questions.question: Which metal is liquid at room temperature?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Mercury is the only metal that remains liquid at room temperature.

questions.question: What type of bond is formed when electrons are shared?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: A covalent bond is formed when atoms share electrons.

questions.question: Who developed the theory of general relativity?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Albert Einstein developed the theory of general relativity in 1915.

questions.question: What is the largest organ in the human body?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: The skin is the largest organ of the human body.

questions.question: Which process do plants use to make their food?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Photosynthesis is how plants produce glucose using sunlight.

questions.question: What is the boiling point of water at sea level?
questions.subject: Everyday Science
questions.explanation: Water boils at 100°C at sea level atmospheric pressure.
